content:
If I view the integers ZZZ as a category with "less than" as the arrows, then the Hasse diagram looks like an infinite line of dots with arrows pointing towards the right.

Z(x,y)Z(x, y)Z(x,y) has the same number of arrows as Z(x+c,y+c)Z(x + c, y +c)Z(x+c,y+c) for all integers c.

So in a sense, "all morphisms between adjacent integers are the same".

You can imagine this category being freely generated by the graph of integers with one edge between nnn and n+1n + 1n+1 for all integers nnn.

I'm trying to do a bit better and clarify what it means to say "all these edges are 'really' just a translation of one edge". To my intuition, there's only one generating arrow of this category. I want to show this without collapsing all the integers into one isomorphic object.

Are there good ways to compare homsets in this way? Can I somehow articulate what it means for homsets to "be the same" even if their objects are not isomorphic?

If you start with a set having a single element, the free monoid generated by that set is the natural numbers, N\mathbb{N}N, together with its usual addition.

We can let this monoid act on the set of integers by addition. So, viewing N\mathbb{N}N as a category with a single object, we get a functor F:N→SetF:\mathbb{N} \to \mathsf{Set}F:N→Set. This functor sends the single object of N\mathbb{N}N to the set of integers. And it sends an element nnn of N\mathbb{N}N to the function x↦x+nx \mapsto x + nx↦x+n, the function which adds nnn to any integer xxx.

I think that the category of elements of FFF is the category you describe above. (Although note that we need to have identity morphisms, so intuitively the arrows correspond to "less than or equal to" instead of "less than"). Checking that this is correct (or proving me wrong!) might be a good exercise to do.

So this process lets us create the category you described starting from (1) a set with a single element and (2) the additive monoid of integers. I'm not sure if noticing that helps answer your question.

@Alex Kreitzberg A functor from a category C→DC\to DC→D has a function Hom(c,c′)→Hom(Fc,Fc′)Hom(c,c') \to Hom(F c, F c')Hom(c,c′)→Hom(Fc,Fc′) for all c,c′c,c'c,c′. If this function is a bijection for all c,c′c,c'c,c′ we say that the functor FFF is fully faithful. The function x↦x+cx\mapsto x+cx↦x+c extends to a fully faithful functor from ZZZ to itself.

A different idea could be as follows. Consider an endofunctor G:C→CG:C \to CG:C→C. If GGG is part of an equivalence of categories, then we might say that C(a,b)C(a,b)C(a,b) is similar in some sense to C(G(a),G(b))C(G(a),G(b))C(G(a),G(b)).

(Edit: I see @Patrick Nicodemus already posted something roughly in this direction!)

Beautiful! I believe these answer my question. Thinking for example about Patrick's FFF and the (you're right less than or equal, sorry!) arrow from l:0→1l : 0 \rightarrow 1l:0→1 as the "generator", I can write all the generating arrows as F(l)nF(l)^{n}F(l)n for some n∈Zn \in \mathbb Zn∈Z.

It's funny, one thought on exploring this, is "what if I have a two dimensional grid, where some of the 'roads' are broken for whatever reason" in that case I think you can have a functor to a category encoding the directions, and the arrows would map to "their direction".

So to define this "direction" functor DDD do the following.

Define a category of directions with one object ⋅\cdot⋅,
So if "up" was u:⋅→⋅u : \cdot \rightarrow \cdotu:⋅→⋅ and "right" was r:⋅→⋅r : \cdot \rightarrow \cdotr:⋅→⋅ then we'd want r∘u=u∘rr \circ u = u \circ rr∘u=u∘r.

DDD will map from the grid Z×Z\mathbb Z \times \mathbb ZZ×Z with some arrows removed, every integer pair maps to ⋅\cdot⋅.

For homsets, if hom((x,y),(x+1,y))hom((x, y), (x + 1, y))hom((x,y),(x+1,y)) is nonempty, its one arrow should then map to rrr, and similarly if hom((x,y),(x,y+1))hom((x, y), (x, y + 1))hom((x,y),(x,y+1)) is nonempty its one arrow should map to uuu.

I think this example is related to but different than David's first example. I'm not sure it can be related to generators cleanly. I guess the functor I described above would be essentially subjective.

But anyways, I think this is all making sense, I'm getting used to manipulating these categories in the manner I want to. Thank you both for your answers.
Alex Kreitzberg has marked this topic as resolved.

Actually one more addendum to that last thought!

Define your arrows across the infinite grid category, omitting some arrows per your whims.

Then quotient the category freely generated on these by the relationships implied by their mapping into the direction category!

That also does what I want I think! Thanks again everybody!

The integers with the usual ≤\le≤ and + is a monoid
object in the category of posets, e.g. the operation + is order-preserving, so we can think of it as a monoidal category where objects are integers and there's a unique morphism from m to n iff m ≤\le≤ n. This fact gives functions

hom(m,n) →\to→ hom(m+k,n+k)

but because the integers are also a group these functions are bijections.

So, we get this whenever we have a monoid object in the category of posets whose underlying monoid is a group. People probably call such a thing a 'partially ordered group'. There are some fun nonabelian examples in physics.

(Note our example is not a group object in the category of posets because negation is order-reversing. I bet the usual definition of 'partially ordered group' assumes or implies that.)
John Baez has marked this topic as unresolved.
(Maybe I'm being silly, but I "unresolved" this question because there's plenty more to say about such things.)
Thanks!! I was not aware of these objects, "partially ordered groups," till today. I find the fact that "group objects in the category of posets are not same as partially ordered groups" interesting.

From the point of nomenclature,

Group object in Set= Set theoretic group(Group)= Group internal to Set
Group objects in Top = Topological group = Group internal to Top
Group objects in Man= Lie group= Group internal to Man
Group objects in Cat= Categorical group(Strict 2-group)= Group internal to Cat
....... so on

but,

Group object in Pos ≠\neq= Partially ordered group ≠\neq= Group internal to Pos (as the inverse function is not order preserving as @John Baez mentioned.)

Question is then, why do we call these objects as "partially ordered groups" ?

Well, the desire to talk about groups that have a partial order came up historically long before anybody realized this terminology would be mildly annoying to later category theorists. Besides, there essentially aren't any group objects in the category of partial orders, so there's little risk of confusion.
I see your point.

I thought it was obvious that there aren't interesting abelian group objects in the category of posets, but now I'm not seeing why.

(I'm saying 'abelian' just to keep things easy: we can write the group operation as + and know x+y =y+x.)

What counts as interesting? We can take any abelian group and make it into an abelian group object in the category of posets by saying x ≥\ge≥ y iff x=y. That counts as uninteresting!

On the other hand suppose we have an abelian group object in the category of posets. If x ≥\ge≥ 0 then we get -x ≥\ge≥ 0, which sounds bad. Oh, I see: then add x to both sides and get 0 ≥\ge≥ x. This then implies x=0.
So: in an abelian group object in the category of posets, if x ≥\ge≥ y then x-y ≥\ge≥ 0 and then by our previous argument x-y =0 so x=y.
So all distinct elements are incomparable. :face_with_symbols_on_mouth:
(That's a QED symbol for theorems that make you angry.)
(just to note that abelianness didn't get used in there)
Good, so it was just a psychological crutch!

Is there a way to axiomatise partially ordered groups with inversion being order-reversing?

I am thinking about the fact that the opposite category is a dual in the monoidal bicategory of profunctors, so presumably the opposite poset is also a dual in some appropriate bicategory of "order-preserving pro-maps".
You could have a symmetric monoidal theory with types PPP and P∗P^*P∗, together with zig-zag equations that specify that the two types are each other's dual, and then this would allow you to specify inversion as an operation of type P→P∗P \to P^*P→P∗, which interpreted in "posets and pro-maps" would be an order-reversing map up to canonical isomorphism.
Well, actually it would be an order-reversing pro-map.
But perhaps it would be possible to define such a theory, so that the models whose operations are "genuine" maps and not pro-maps are exactly partially ordered groups.
Another way to specify them is "the pullback in Cat\mathsf{Cat}Cat of the forgetful functor from partially ordered monoids to monoids along the forgetful functor from groups to monoids".

Yeah, it seems to me like there are all sorts of good reasons to treat “existence of inverses” as a property of monoids rather than an operation --- iirc the most useful categorifications of Hopf algebras (those that satisfy the “most correct” categorified Tannaka reconstruction theorems) do not admit the antipode as an operation --- but I am curious about whether in this particular case one can still make things work in terms of categorical universal algebra.

Interestingly, this article by Gunnar Fløystad starts with

This article advocates for general posets P and Q the notion of profunctor P -|→ Q as more effective than the notion of isotone (order preserving) maps P → Q between posets, especially for applications in algebra.

So it may be worth looking at generalised partially ordered groups as models of a symmetric monoidal theory in posets and profunctors (or pro-maps).

I'd conjecture that this could be an interesting set of generators and relations for a symmetric monoidal theory (a coloured prop): we would have two types PPP and P∗P^*P∗, and as generators

  • the multiplication and unit of a monoid structure on PPP, i.e. m:P⊗P→Pm: P \otimes P \to Pm:P⊗P→P and u:I→Pu: I \to Pu:I→P,
  • the antipode s:P∗→Ps: P^* \to Ps:P∗→P,
  • the unit and counit of a duality between PPP and P∗P^*P∗, η:I→P⊗P∗\eta: I \to P \otimes P^*η:I→P⊗P∗ and ε:P∗⊗P→I\varepsilon: P^* \otimes P \to Iε:P∗⊗P→I.

We also have, structurally, symmetric bradings σ∙,∙\sigma_{\bullet,\bullet}σ∙,∙​.

As equations we would have

  1. equations saying that mmm and uuu give a monoid structure on PPP,
  2. zig-zag equations saying that η\etaη and ε\varepsilonε make PPP and P∗P^*P∗ into each other's dual,
  3. the equation m∘(idP⊗s)∘η=u∘(ε∘σP,P∗∘η)m \circ (\mathrm{id}_P \otimes s) \circ \eta = u \circ (\varepsilon \circ \sigma_{P, P^*} \circ \eta)m∘(idP​⊗s)∘η=u∘(ε∘σP,P∗​∘η)

Here ε∘σP,P∗∘η\varepsilon \circ \sigma_{P, P^*} \circ \etaε∘σP,P∗​∘η is the abstract dimension of PPP i.e. the trace of idP\mathrm{id}_PidP​, which is a scalar.

The idea I have in my mind is that m∘(idP⊗s)∘ηm \circ (\mathrm{id}_P \otimes s) \circ \etam∘(idP​⊗s)∘η should behave formally like

∑x∈Px⋅x−1\sum_{x \in P} x \cdot x^{-1}∑x∈P​x⋅x−1

while u∘dim(P)u \circ \mathrm{dim}(P)u∘dim(P) is like ∣P∣1P|P| 1_P∣P∣1P​, where 1P1_P1P​ is the group unit and ∣P∣|P|∣P∣ the cardinality of PPP, so this is the equation I'd expect.
It's interesting that this theory does not require a comonoid structure unlike the usual “Hopf algebra”-like presentation of groups.
(Perhaps it would make sense to move this to a separate thread, sorry for diverting this one.)

Amar Hadzihasanovic said:

Is there a way to axiomatise partially ordered groups with inversion being order-reversing?

This property, that inversion is order-reversing, follows from the usual definition of partially ordered group, which I believe is equivalent to "a monoid in posets whose underlying monoid in sets is a group". (You mentioned this approach later.)

Given such a thing we see that given

x ≥\ge≥ y

we can add -y to both sides and get

x - y ≥\ge≥ 0

and then add -x to both sides and get

-y ≥\ge≥ -x

so negation is order-reversing.

(I'm using additive notation but not assuming abelianness.)

So, if the existence of inverses is treated as a mere property of a monoid in posets, they automatically obey this law.

But it's still fun to think about other approaches!

Ok so I think I can at least show that every partially ordered group is, indeed, a model of the theory that I described.

As a preliminary, let me describe the category of posets and pro-maps more explicitly, in the style of the paper by Fløystad:

  • the objects are posets,
  • the morphisms P→QP \to QP→Q are order-preserving maps f:P→Q^f: P \to \hat{Q}f:P→Q^​, where Q^\hat{Q}Q^​ is the poset of lower sets of QQQ (a lower set of a poset is a subset UUU with the property that x≤yx \leq yx≤y and y∈Uy \in Uy∈U implies x∈Ux \in Ux∈U)
  • an order-preserving map f:P→Q^f: P \to \hat{Q}f:P→Q^​ determines an order-preserving, union-preserving map f^:P^→Q^\hat{f}: \hat{P} \to \hat{Q}f^​:P^→Q^​ by U↦⋃x∈Uf(x)U \mapsto \bigcup_{x \in U} f(x)U↦⋃x∈U​f(x); we compose two morphisms P→QP \to QP→Q and Q→RQ \to RQ→R, determined by maps f:P→Q^f: P \to \hat{Q}f:P→Q^​ and g:Q→R^g: Q \to \hat{R}g:Q→R^, by letting g^∘f:P→R^\hat{g} \circ f: P \to \hat{R}g^​∘f:P→R^ be the composite;
  • the identity on PPP is determined by the map P→P^P \to \hat{P}P→P^ sending x∈Px \in Px∈P to its lower set ↓x={y≤x}\downarrow x = \{y \leq x \}↓x={y≤x}.

(This is really an instance of enriched profunctors where the basis of enrichment is the ordinal 2\mathbf{2}2; the map P→P^P \to \hat{P}P→P^ is the 2\mathbf{2}2-enriched Yoneda embedding)

The cartesian product of posets determines a symmetric monoidal structure on this category.
With respect to this symmetric monoidal structure, the opposite poset PopP^\mathrm{op}Pop is a two-sided dual to PPP:

  • first of all, observe that 1^\hat{1}1^, the poset of lower sets of the terminal poset, is the ordinal 2\mathbf{2}2, since the only lower sets of 111 are ∅\varnothing∅ and 111;
  • the counit of the duality is the pro-map Pop×P→1^P^\mathrm{op} \times P \to \hat{1}Pop×P→1^ sending (x,y)(x, y)(x,y) to 111 if and only if x≤yx \leq yx≤y, and to ∅\varnothing∅ otherwise;
  • the unit of the duality is the pro-map 1→(P×Pop)^1 \to \widehat{(P \times P^\mathrm{op})}1→(P×Pop)​ which picks the set of pairs (x,y)(x, y)(x,y) such that x≤yx \leq yx≤y; observe that this is indeed a lower set in P×PopP \times P^\mathrm{op}P×Pop.

Now I claim that every partially ordered group gives a model of the theory that I described a few posts before.

  • Interpret the type PPP as the underlying poset of the partially ordered group, and P∗P^*P∗ as the opposite poset PopP^\mathrm{op}Pop.
  • To interpret the multiplication and unit, post-compose the order-preserving maps m:P×P→Pm: P \times P \to Pm:P×P→P and u:1→Pu: 1 \to Pu:1→P with the Yoneda embedding P→P^P \to \hat{P}P→P^.
  • To interpret the antipode, post-compose the order-reversing map s:Pop→Ps: P^\mathrm{op} \to Ps:Pop→P, x↦x−1x \mapsto x^{-1}x↦x−1 with the Yoneda embedding P→P^P \to \hat{P}P→P^.
  • To interpret the unit and counit of duality, use the unit and counit pro-maps I just described.

Now the equations relative to multiplication and unit follow immediately from the fact that a partially ordered group is in particular an internal monoid in (posets, order-preserving maps, cartesian product), and post-composing with the Yoneda embedding determines a monoidal functor from this to (posets, pro-maps, cartesian product).

The equations relative to duality follow from the fact that indeed PPP and PopP^\mathrm{op}Pop are duals.

Finally, by calculation, m∘(idP×s)∘ηm \circ (\mathrm{id}_P \times s) \circ \etam∘(idP​×s)∘η picks the lower set

⋃{ ↓xy−1∣x,y∈P,x≤y }\bigcup \set{ \downarrow xy^{-1} \mid x, y \in P, x \leq y}⋃{↓xy−1∣x,y∈P,x≤y}

But if x≤yx \leq yx≤y then xy−1≤1Pxy^{-1} \leq 1_Pxy−1≤1P​ where 1P1_P1P​ is the group unit, so ↓xy−1⊆↓1P\downarrow xy^{-1} \subseteq \downarrow 1_P↓xy−1⊆↓1P​, so this union is included in ↓1P\downarrow 1_P↓1P​; and conversely, since x≤xx \leq xx≤x for each x∈Px \in Px∈P, the lower set ↓1P\downarrow 1_P↓1P​ is included in the union, so overall this is just picking the lower set of the group unit.

Now, there are only 2 scalars in this monoidal category --- the elements of 2\mathbf{2}2 --- and dim(P)\mathrm{dim}(P)dim(P) is ∅\varnothing∅ if PPP is empty, and 111 otherwise. Since every partially ordered group is nonempty, dim(P)\mathrm{dim}(P)dim(P) is 111 that is the unit scalar.

So we have, indeed, m∘(idP×s)∘η=u∘dim(P)=um \circ (\mathrm{id}_P \times s) \circ \eta = u \circ \mathrm{dim}(P) = um∘(idP​×s)∘η=u∘dim(P)=u, since both sides pick the lower set of the group unit.

To give one example of models of this theory where the presence of dim(P)\mathrm{dim}(P)dim(P) in the final equation is non-trivial, I claim that the free kkk-vector space kGkGkG on a finite group GGG gives a model of my theory in the compact closed category of kkk-vector spaces with the tensor product:

  • the dual of kGkGkG is taken to be kGkGkG itself, the unit is defined by 1k↦∑g∈Gg⊗g1_k \mapsto \sum_{g \in G} g \otimes g1k​↦∑g∈G​g⊗g and counit by g⊗h↦1kg \otimes h \mapsto 1_kg⊗h↦1k​ if g=hg = hg=h and 0k0_k0k​ if g≠hg \neq hg=h,
  • mmm, uuu, sss are all linear extensions of the corresponding maps on the elements of ggg.

Then, indeed, m∘(idkG⊗s)∘ηm \circ (\mathrm{id}_{kG} \otimes s) \circ \etam∘(idkG​⊗s)∘η is the map 1k↦∑g∈Ggg−1=(∣G∣1k)1G1_k \mapsto \sum_{g \in G} gg^{-1} = (|G|1_k) 1_G1k​↦∑g∈G​gg−1=(∣G∣1k​)1G​, which is equal to u∘dim(kG)u \circ \mathrm{dim}(kG)u∘dim(kG) since the dimension of kGkGkG is equal to ∣G∣1k|G|1_k∣G∣1k​.

Amar Hadzihasanovic said:

iirc the most useful categorifications of Hopf algebras (those that satisfy the “most correct” categorified Tannaka reconstruction theorems) do not admit the antipode as an operation

Could you clarify what's this "most correct" categorification of Hopf algebras and why it has no notion of an antipode? Are you referring perhaps to rigid monoidal cats? Or maybe trialgebras? Any references?

While thinking about binary algebras, I better understood the significance behind Baez's suggestion to think of monoid objects in the category of posets.

Suppose you're given a monoid MMM, we can make this into a preorder by drawing an arrow between two elements aaa and ccc if there exists an element bbb such that ab=cab = cab=c, denote this condition by a∣ca | ca∣c. We can even label such an arrow bbb.

This is a preorder because a∣aa | aa∣a and a∣ba | ba∣b with b∣cb | cb∣c implies a∣ca | ca∣c. (proof: a1=1,ax′=b,bx′′=c  ⟹  ax′x′′=ca1 = 1, ax' = b, bx'' = c \implies ax'x'' = ca1=1,ax′=b,bx′′=c⟹ax′x′′=c)

1∣x1 | x1∣x for all x∈Mx \in Mx∈M, making the identity initial.

If our monoid is commutative then it's monotonic, If a∣ca | ca∣c and b∣db | db∣d, then ab∣cdab | cdab∣cd.

There's a more complicated story here involving left division and right division that I wasn't able to sort out. Maybe Amar was able to get a good chunk of it sorted, but I don't need it right now.

Homomorphisms preserve divisibility, ab=c  ⟹  ϕ(a)ϕ(b)=ϕ(c)ab =c \implies \phi(a)\phi(b) = \phi(c)ab=c⟹ϕ(a)ϕ(b)=ϕ(c) for all homomorphisms ϕ\phiϕ. So homomorphisms are also naturally monotonic maps with respect to this definition.

This gives us the structure of our functor O:CommMon→OrdCommMonO : \mathsf{Comm Mon} \rightarrow \mathsf{Ord Comm Mon}O:CommMon→OrdCommMon

let fff and ggg be composable monoid homomorphisms. Then O(f∘g)(x)=f(g(x))=O(f)(O(g)(x))O(f \circ g)(x) = f(g(x)) = O(f)(O(g)(x))O(f∘g)(x)=f(g(x))=O(f)(O(g)(x)), that is OOO preserves the composition because all it's doing is noting the presence of an extra property of functions, monotonicity. (The identity is trivially preserved)

So we have a functor on commutative monoids giving them an order! We can forget this preorder to get back our original monoid, or we could keep the preorder and forget it came from a monoid. Call these forgetful functors UMonU_{\mathsf{Mon}}UMon​ and UPreU_{\mathsf{Pre}}UPre​.

This gives an interesting way to frame some questions I was trying to ask about these objects. For example, the natural number preorder, ignoring its monoid structure, seems to uniquely define natural numbers. I suspect that means the fiber over the preorder NNN under the functor UPreOU_{\mathsf{Pre}}OUPre​O, is a contractible groupoid containing the monoid NNN.

If this is provable that would be a really fun way of answering my original question "How to show the distinct homsets are the same?" for the special cases I was exploring.

I'm struggling to get a handle on all the moving parts though so maybe there's an even more interesting and general story here.

In any case, I started thinking about this again, because while trying to understand Setop\mathsf{Set}^{\text{op}}Setop by reading the wikipedia article Boolean algebras canonically defined (Date: 4/21/2025), I noticed the article referred to a lattice basis vs a ring basis for thinking about boolean logic.

So I suspect there's a similar sort of Functor dance between commutative rings and preorders, which in the special case of boolean logic lets us use lattices ( the usual propositional calculus way ) or algebra.

I have a bunch more ideas connected to this stuff, and I'm not convinced I didn't make a mistake above. But I still wanted to leave a note here to keep my thoughts organized.

Interestingly this preorder you're putting on commutative monoids featured recently in my conversation with @Adittya Chaudhuri. We were using it to define the 'minimal' elements of certain commutative monoids we're studying.

You say this process gives a functor

O:CommMon→OrdCommMonO : \mathsf{Comm Mon} \rightarrow \mathsf{Ord Comm Mon}O:CommMon→OrdCommMon

from commutative monoids to preordered commutative monoids, which sounds right, and you also mention the (more obvious) functor

U:OrdCommMon→CommMon U : \mathsf{Ord Comm Mon} \rightarrow \mathsf{Comm Mon}U:OrdCommMon→CommMon

which forgets the preorder. But now you're making me wonder:

Question: is OOO the left adjoint of UUU?

Interesting!! If OOO is really a left adjoint to UUU, then we may compose the functor OOO with the free monoid functor Free ⁣:Set→CommMonFree \colon \mathsf{Set} \to \mathsf{CommMon}Free:Set→CommMon to obtain an adjoint pair of functors between Set\mathsf{Set}Set and OrdCommMon\mathsf{OrdCommMon}OrdCommMon.

I haven't checked whether OOO is left adjoint to UUU, but I have a pretty good understanding of

O∘Free:Set→OrdCommMon O \circ \text{Free} : \mathsf{Set} \to \textsf{OrdCommMon}O∘Free:Set→OrdCommMon,

so I might as well share it with anyone who doesn't. If XXX is a set, O(Free(X))O(\text{Free}(X))O(Free(X)) is the commutative monoid whose elements are functions

f:X→N f: X \to \mathbb{N}f:X→N

such that f(x)=0f(x) = 0f(x)=0 except for finitely many x∈Xx \in Xx∈X, made into a commutative monoid with the addition defined by

(f+g)(x)=f(x)+g(x) (f + g)(x) = f(x) + g(x) (f+g)(x)=f(x)+g(x)

and the preorder (in fact a partial order) defined by

f≤g  ⟺  ∀x∈X  f(x)≤g(x) f \le g \iff \forall x \in X \; f(x) \le g(x) f≤g⟺∀x∈Xf(x)≤g(x)

So it's a very nice thing! The morphisms are arbitrary commutative monoid homomorphisms, which automatically preserve the partial order.
Thanks!! It is interesting!
(deleted)

I think whether OOO is left adjoint to UUU depends on what I mean by OrdCommMon\mathsf{OrdCommMon}OrdCommMon.

If I mean "commutative monoid object in the category of preorders" I think the answer is no, because there's nothing stopping me from giving any monoid a trivial order with only reflexive comparisons. And such an ordered monoid has almost no monotonic functions into it, but lots of monoid homomorphisms into the underlying monoid.

However, if OrdCommMon\mathsf{OrdCommMon}OrdCommMon requires for any object MMM, we have 0≤m0 \leq m0≤m for all m∈Mm \in Mm∈M and a+b=c  ⟹  a≤ca + b = c \implies a \leq ca+b=c⟹a≤c, then I think OOO is a left adjoint.

I can't quite tell whether that's a natural definition for a category of ordered commutative monoids though.
Your second condition implies your first. Also, the second condition is basically just saying the order of MMM is an extension of the order of OUMOUMOUM.
Is it being an extension "boring" or overly restrictive? Or are you giving me a suggestion for how to say what I mean?

I think OOO just gives the minimal preordering on a commutative monoid that makes addition inflationary in all arguments. But I can't think of a nice way to phrase that like "living in a certain category" because being inflationary only makes sense for endomorphisms.
It's up to you whether being an extension bores you or not, but it does make the fact that OOO ends up being the left adjoint rather tautologous.

Given that, I think the answer to Baez's question is "no".

While thinking about this and similar orders on monoids it did get me to wonder if I could find a functor C:Pre→MonC : \mathsf{Pre} \rightarrow \mathsf{Mon}C:Pre→Mon such that Pre(O(m),p)≅Mon(m,C(p))\mathsf{Pre}(O(m), p) \cong \mathsf{Mon}(m, C(p))Pre(O(m),p)≅Mon(m,C(p)) was an adjunction.

But I wasn't able to solidify the definitions into a form that did what I wanted.

And the more I thought about it the less I was convinced it was true as written.

But the idea was given a sufficiently nice pre-order maybe there was a monoid dual to it.
I was going to come back to it after understanding adjoint functors a bit better.

I had another idea, that I think is more standard. Let MMM be a monoid that acts on itself, this describes a functor M(⋅,−):M→SetM(\cdot, -) : M \rightarrow SetM(⋅,−):M→Set, and then the preorder I described before is just the category of elements of this functor.

We have a forgetful functor from the category of elements, to the category it was built off of. Which in this case gives us back our original monoid, so this probably has an interesting adjoint.

Now, unless I confused myself somehow, I think my initial simple category {⋅→⋅→…}\{\cdot \rightarrow \cdot \rightarrow \ldots\}{⋅→⋅→…} is equivalent to the preorder category view of natural numbers N\mathbb{N}N, which is equivalent to the category of elements of hom(N,−)\text{hom}(\mathbb{N}, -)hom(N,−) (here N\mathbb{N}N is viewed as a monoid), which is a forgetful functor away from N\mathbb{N}N viewed as a monoid.

This deserves more explicit proofs, but I wanted to put a note here because if it works, I think it answers my original question in a very nice way.

And maybe it'll also help me spell out the dual relationship between the algebraic and preorder point of views of logical structures.
